description: From Middle English biveren,  beveren (“to tremble”), frequentative form of Old English beofian, bifian (“to tremble, be moved, shake, quake”), from Proto-Germanic *bibāną (“to quake, shiver”). Cognate with West Frisian bibberje (“to shiver”), Dutch bibberen (“to shiver, quiver”), Low German beveren (“to shiver”), German Low German bevern (“to tremble”), German bibbern (“to shiver”). related also to Dutch beven (“to quake”), German beben (“to quake, tremble”), Swedish bäva (“to quake, tremble”), Icelandic bifa (“to budge, be moved”), Latin foedus (“disgusting, shocking, abominable, heinous”).

verbs.description: bever (third-person singular simple present bevers, present participle bevering, simple past and past participle bevered)

examples: Wherefore King Ban and King Bors made them ready, and dressed their shields and harness, and they were so courageous that many knights shook and bevered for eagerness.

Some close helmets have a farther improvement called a bever, the bever when closed covers the mouth and chin, and either lifts up by revolving on the same pivots as the visor, or lets down by means of two or more pivots on each side near the jaws, in which case the bever consists of several laminæ or plates, one shutting over the other.

description: From Middle English bever, from Anglo-Norman bever (modern French boire), from Latin bibō.

entries.meaning: (now rare, archaic) A snack or light refreshment between meals.
examples: Thirty meals a day and ten bevers.

entries.meaning: A mixture of cider and water.

verbs.description: bever (third-person singular simple present bevers, present participle bevering, simple past and past participle bevered)

entries.meaning: (obsolete) To take a light repast between meals.
